Sincere props to everybody involved with producing this incredible strategy game. There's so many things Old World does right that sets it apart from the competition.

[list]
    [*]The #1 thing I want to highlight is the fantastic UI/UX. Strategy games can hide a lot of complexity only emphasizing the need for clear and obvious information. It's here where the game really shines. UI panels are intuitive to read and stuffed with helpful details. Game concepts are written as hyperlinks you can repeatedly SHIFT-CLICK to expose stacking detail panels. The encyclopedia is well written. Boundary lines are clear, unit move distance is apparent, everything just comes together nicely to make the learning experience smooth and engaging.
    [*]This is the first strategy game I've played offering an undo button. Did you accidentally click the wrong hex when scouting or make a tactical blunder in combat? CTRL-Z to undo. Want to experiment with a few moves and see their impact? Feel free because you can undo an entire turn if things don't work out. I never realized how much I needed this.
    [*]Old World introduced an orders system that governs how many moves you can execute per turn. This was the thing I was most excited to try out and I'm happy to say it leads to an intriguing puzzle to solve. You have 27 orders this turn...do you want to spend that scouting, engaging in warfare, building up your nation, dealing in politics, or do you instead bank them for extra gold? Some turns you won't have enough orders to do everything you want, others you struggle to even spend them all. Combine that with the undo action and it makes each turn feel truly dynamic.
    [*]The leaders and politics are fascinating. You're constantly managing reputation and finding ways to effectively utilize these powerful figures from ancient history. Lines of succession get redrawn amidst death, marriage, and children getting born into the family. All your characters visually age over time making you feel connected to them, and some of the choices personal.
    [*]Throughout the game you're presented with so many rich and satisfying decisions. There's numerous resources to juggle. Technology is randomized each game. Events frequently present themselves with a cause and effect scenario. Leaders level up giving you choices about how to shape your nation. Workers have an abundance of rural and urban improvements to build. Combine all of that with the orders system and it's just endless fun to tickle your brain. I end each round with anticipation, begin new ones with enthusiasm, and find it difficult to deny just one more turn.
    [*]Combat is actually tactical beyond your standard rock-paper-scissor unit composition. Spearman target enemies in a line, axemen attack multiple units in an arc, cavalry can route (attack again after defeating an enemy), some units benefit from adjacency. Generals can be assigned to units to further enhance their capability while also leveling up.
    [*]And the music...OMG they chose some real beauties here. You can't go wrong enlisting Christopher Tin. Songs you dislike you can disable from rotation. And in a clever touch the music doesn't actually kick in until you've researched drama, at which point this game soars above the clouds.
[/list]

As a long time Civilization fanatic who mourns the downfall of my favorite franchise (starting at civ 6), I hereby unofficially nominate Old World as the official standard bearer of the civ like 4X genre. I also officially nominated them for the "Labor of Love" steam awards.

Pros: 
-Hands down the most well thought out gameplay mechanics of any recent 4X 
-Excellent storytelling ability via its situationally proccing events
-Meaningful diplomacy that integrates into the event system
-Strategic combat with good utilization of terrain 
-Outcomes in combat that have overlap with the events system
-Surprisingly clever AI opponents

Cons:

-A half hearted implementation of a CK3 style family tree minigame. It has good bones, but seems to never have really been fleshed out in a way that has a meaningful impact on your gameplay. I want to care about my family members more, but sometimes all the characters just blur together.

-While Old World has many similarities to the Civilization franchise, it lacks a certain kind of charm that Civ has. I think its likely due to the narrow time period in which the game covers. While a game in civ can span from the ancient to the modern, OW really only covers a narrow slice of a specific historical time period. While in theory this focus has some upsides, it kind of translates into bland progression of the technology tree. Most new units are just slightly more powerful versions of their earlier counterparts, but otherwise thematically identical.

-Poor end game experience despite good intentions. In an attempt to remedy the end game grind that other 4X games are plagued by, the OW implemented an "ambitions" mechanic which essentially finishes the game after meeting a set number of smaller incremental goals (similar to a light version of victory conditions in Civ). While I enjoy this mechanic throughout the game as a fun incentive for accomplishing specific actions, I find it to be both an unsatisfying and anticlimactic way to finish a game. Instead of rethinking the end-game grind, OW devs seemed to have tried to sidestep the end-game all together. But if you're like me in that you enjoy long drawn out domination victories, OW suffers from the usual late-game fatigue involving tedious levels of micromanagement. Do you enjoy dragging 50 units across a large map one-by-one? Me neither. And while technically you can automate workers and cities, the bad AI for this renders it practically un-useable (in stark contrast to the excellent combat and diplomacy AI). Conversely, I feel like there could be some innovative event based solutions to these issues, but surfacing them would require a handful of outside-of-the-box brainstorming sessions (with possible chemical enhancement required for increased lateral thinking).

Overall:

Despite some glaring flaws, Old World does so much right that others in the 4X genre could really learn from. As evidenced by my playtime, it is objectively one of my favorite games. If you enjoy the 4X genre, it might just become one of your favorites too.

One neat mechanic is that each turn you have a set amount of "Orders" to work with, which you get based on what you've done in game. You can divvy these up as you want between your units, such that you can have turns where some units move extra, and other's don't move. Another interesting mechanic is that the technologies you research are a deck. When you unlock a new tech and new options open up, those new options go to your discard pile. When you get the option to research, you get dealt a hand to choose from. (there are also some one-shot effects on cards that you can mix in as well.)

TLDR: I became aware of the game some months ago and it soon developed into one of my favourite games. Thus, I can really recommend it. The complexity, level of strategy depth and historical flavour of this strategy game are really outstanding.

The Good:

- The game has a level of complexity and interconnectedness of game mechanics that are rarely found in gaming. This is one of the few examples of games that still try to simulate a world instead of streamlining the mechanics to the point that it could also be a board game. (Don't get me wrong: I really like board games. But if you can use the processing power of a computer to simulate a world, you should do that.)

- The AI in this game is really good, one of the best I have ever played against. (I do not consider myself a hardcore gamer and winning an epic victory in scenario 3 of the Carthage Campaign really makes me proud.)

- This game ouzes historical flavour. This already shows in normal games, but the campaigns are really great! Not only have I had lots of fun, I also learned a lot.

- The soundtrack is great. (You have to research "Drama" ingame for the music to start, which is a nice detail)

- The long term support for the game is great. Many larger companies should take note how regularly and transparently this small indie company supports their game.

- The base game is really good as a standalone and the DLCs really are optional. I own each DLC and I love all of them, but I cannot stress this enough: This game is not the typical jigsaw puzzle which is unplayable without buying each DLC, but a really good game all on its own. You can have lots of fun just with the base game and later add in all the DLC you like to get more content (like new campaigns) or deepen certain game mechanics.

The Bad:

- The good AI comes with a price and the price is payed in computational ressources. Even on newer computers turns in the late game can take some time due to all the background computations that need to be made in order to get such a competent AI.

The Up to Taste:

[h1]Multiplayer Wargame With 4X Foundation[/h1]

[h2]Fatigue, Information Overload and Ugliness Earn Old World A 2 Out of 5[/h2]

[b]THE GOOD: Cities and specialists; Pings; Undo; Orders; Vassal Families[/b]

[b]THE BAD: Diplomacy; Religion; Espionage; Influence Actions[/b]

[b]THE UGLY: Neverending text; Everything looks the same; Data displays are crude and ugly; A very rough UI[/b]

Old World is for lawyers and gamblers, not for engineers or accountants. It has some interesting concepts which enhance gameplay by exploiting the natural tension between freedom and constraints. I hope others duplicate the conceptual innovations in Old World and improve upon them in other 4X titles.

Old World's user interface is text- and number-dense. Playing beyond about four hours leads to a sense of fatigue and information overload. Things one might like to plan ahead of time, e.g. technological research or military unit promotions, are wrapped in random processes that appeal to devil-may-care gamblers but drive deliberate strategists mad. Frustration sets in when one tries to learn one's lessons from previous losses, only to be stymied because one can't make long-term plans for structural reasons intrinsic to the game. These structural aspects aggravate the information overload precisely because they make long-term strategic planning so exasperating.

Old World's intended audience is players seeking a Multiplayer Wargaming experience with a 4X foundation. Many (most?) experienced Old World players value the developers' attention to aspects of Multiplayer gameplay that were absent from or very poorly implemented in other 4X titles. I exclusively play Single Player, and though I enjoy stomping my annoying neighbors' guts out as much as anyone, that's not the only way I play 4X games. The victory conditions are boring, especially the Ambitions Victory, which, for structural reasons described previously, is challenging for all the wrong reasons.

Many positive reviewers on Steam reveal themselves to be unserious, as they are enthusiasts, fanbois and gatekeepers who abandon their critical faculties in defense of a game they believe is under-appreciated and not well publicized. Both of these things may be true of Old World but reviews don't settle scores. "Historical" justifications of Old World come either from fools or charlatans. The game's many grossly ahistorical elements are documented and criticized in detail elsewhere. Old World is "history based," at best. It is [i]not[/i] "historical." There's nothing wrong with that! But don't try to church up Old World with assertions of historicity.

[b]THE GOOD:[/b]
[b]1. City limits, workable tiles and specialists.[/b] There's usually a way to get what you want where you want it, though not necessarily when you need it. Borders can grow stupidly, which should be fixed, e.g., don't give that unincorporated wheat to my Champions city when my Landowners city is within equal range.

[b]2. The Ping system[/b] is great for planning improvements. Reminder pings need improvement. Setting a reminder ping to, say, promote a military unit on turn X will cause the ping message to post in the long list of messages delivered at the start of turn X, but the map pin is immediately removed! Leave time-sensitive pings on the map until they're acknowledged or removed manually.

[b]3. Undo is wonderful![/b] Make the Actions Stack viewable so that the player can easily select the last event they want to "keep" when they undo Actions.

[b]4. The Orders concept[/b] is an interesting constraint on player actions. Are the computer players also so constrained? The need for the player to decide which actions to take this turn (vs. later or maybe never) limits one's horizons, but it presents a challenge that's interesting to deal with.

[b]5. The Vassal Families system[/b] presents interesting challenges. Why aren't all 10 vassal families available to every civilization? Keep the limit of only three Families per empire. There's no good reason to arbitrarily make it impossible for a particular civilization to incorporate any of the different Vassal Families, so long as there are never more than three Families present in the empire.

[b]THE BAD:[/b]
[b]1. The Diplomacy system stinks.[/b] It's too limited and it's lame that an Ambassador is required in order to take any diplomatic action. It's reasonable to require an Ambassador to conduct diplomacy with other Civilizations. It's unreasonable to require an Ambassador to conduct diplomacy with Tribes. The few Ambassador Actions available suggest that the Diplomacy system was just bolted onto the game rather than developed right from the beginning. My Orders are better spent elsewhere.

[b]2. The Religion system stinks.[/b] Like Diplomacy, Religion seems like an afterthought. Civilizations without Clerics Families or that don't start the game with the Divination technology or with the Husbandry technology will almost never found a World Religion except by sheer accident due to a random Event. Pagan Religions are second-class to World Religions, making them a short-term sink of one's precious Orders, so why bother?

[b]3. The Espionage system is weak.[/b] It's reasonable to require a Spymaster to conduct Espionage Missions against other Civilizations. It's unreasonable to require a Spymaster to, e.g., "deal with" my rotten jealous scheming twin brother who lives forever and is an irredeemable nuisance and DEFCON 1 threat to my Rule and my household. It's completely arbitrary that all the nasty things one might need to do without being noticed within one's own civilization are off limits until one reaches the developmental stage at which it is also possible to foment unrest in foreign lands or steal technologies from adversaries. And Spymasters can't stir up the Tribes.

[b]4. Influence Actions are too limited.[/b] One Character can only attempt to Influence ("A chats up B") another Character exactly one time, ever, throughout the entire lives of both Characters (A and B). One Character can only be Interceded For ("C chats up B on A's behalf") one time, ever, throughout the entire lives of both principal Characters (A and B). And during Leadership transitions, womp womp Legitimacy tanks! Good luck getting all your VIPs happily in line. You get one shot and one shot only per Influence target. What am I, made of Orders? Better to spend them on sure things.

[b]THE UGLY:[/b]
[b]1. "Yo I heard you like reading."[/b] Everything that's not the map terrain itself is text. Tiny icons and tiny text litter the map, every notification is text... you'll do so much reading and clicking through menus in Old World that you'll suffer eye strain. Tooltips and text labels need different typefaces to separate and highlight different bits of information. The net effect is information overload. Animations and voice acting for Events would do wonders to liven things up.

[b]2. All the improvements look the same.[/b] Each improvement type looks identical across all Civilizations, lacking any national or regional character. Is it all made out of ticky-tacky?

[b]3. Tables, charts and graphs are more crude and ugly than useful.[/b] For example, the Family Opinion chart. One sees three traces plotted vs. time. Three numbers, that's it! Information, especially numerical data, is presented in a very limited and visually unappealing way that screams "SuSE Linux, circa 2003."

[b]4. The UI is fiddly and sticky.[/b] Tooltips with tooltips on their tooltips make for a very fiddly experience. There's a lot of clicking this and clicking that and having to drag the map this way and that, which worsens player fatigue caused by turn after turn of textalanche. Units cycle in a fixed order, bouncing from one end of the map to the other. One can automate Scouts and Workers, but military units need their hands held every step they take.

[h1]A Beautiful Disappointment: Ambition Without Execution[/h1]
I'm a history buff and a fan of 4X games, so Old World should have been perfect for me. The concept is compelling - a 4X game set in antiquity with dynastic mechanics and character-driven narratives. The art direction is beautiful, and I think the developers had good intentions. Unfortunately, that doesn't make up for the game's problems.
[hr][/hr]
[b]The Identity Crisis[/b]
Old World feels like it's trying to be three different games at once: Civilization's empire-building, Europa Universalis' depth, and Hearts of Iron's strategic complexity. It doesn't succeed at being any of them. It's stuck in an awkward middle ground where it's too shallow for grand strategy enthusiasts but too convoluted for casual 4X players.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Forced Ideology and Limited Agency[/b]
One of my biggest frustrations is how the game pushes contemporary cultural expectations and ideals into your face during gameplay. Mods can fix this (thankfully), but it shouldn't require community intervention to make a historical game feel less like social commentary. I play these games to engage with history on its own terms, not to have modern sensibilities imposed on ancient civilizations.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Shallow Systems[/b]
The problem-solving paths are severely gated and limited compared to what Europa Universalis offers. When challenges arise, you're forced down narrow story-driven solutions rather than having real strategic options. The economics feel underbaked, and production times are painfully long without the depth to justify it. Everything takes forever, but nothing feels particularly rewarding when completed.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Better Options Exist[/b]
I wanted this to work, but there are simply better games out there. If you want accessible 4X gameplay, Civilization V (or earlier) does it better. For grand strategy depth, Europa Universalis IV is superior. For character-driven narratives, Crusader Kings III excels. Even older games like Endless Legend or Endless Space offer more satisfying experiences.
Old World falls short in nearly every category it attempts. I can't recommend it when superior alternatives exist at similar or lower price points.

[h1]Multiplayer Wargame With 4X Foundation[/h1]

[h2]Fatigue, Information Overload and Ugliness Earn Old World A 2 Out of 5[/h2]

[b]THE GOOD: Cities and specialists; Pings; Undo; Orders; Vassal Families[/b]

[b]THE BAD: Diplomacy; Religion; Espionage; Influence Actions[/b]

[b]THE UGLY: Neverending text; Everything looks the same; Data displays are crude and ugly; A very rough UI[/b]

Old World is for lawyers and gamblers, not for engineers or accountants. It has some interesting concepts which enhance gameplay by exploiting the natural tension between freedom and constraints. I hope others duplicate the conceptual innovations in Old World and improve upon them in other 4X titles.

Old World's user interface is text- and number-dense. Playing beyond about four hours leads to a sense of fatigue and information overload. Things one might like to plan ahead of time, e.g. technological research or military unit promotions, are wrapped in random processes that appeal to devil-may-care gamblers but drive deliberate strategists mad. Frustration sets in when one tries to learn one's lessons from previous losses, only to be stymied because one can't make long-term plans for structural reasons intrinsic to the game. These structural aspects aggravate the information overload precisely because they make long-term strategic planning so exasperating.

Old World's intended audience is players seeking a Multiplayer Wargaming experience with a 4X foundation. Many (most?) experienced Old World players value the developers' attention to aspects of Multiplayer gameplay that were absent from or very poorly implemented in other 4X titles. I exclusively play Single Player, and though I enjoy stomping my annoying neighbors' guts out as much as anyone, that's not the only way I play 4X games. The victory conditions are boring, especially the Ambitions Victory, which, for structural reasons described previously, is challenging for all the wrong reasons.

Many positive reviewers on Steam reveal themselves to be unserious, as they are enthusiasts, fanbois and gatekeepers who abandon their critical faculties in defense of a game they believe is under-appreciated and not well publicized. Both of these things may be true of Old World but reviews don't settle scores. "Historical" justifications of Old World come either from fools or charlatans. The game's many grossly ahistorical elements are documented and criticized in detail elsewhere. Old World is "history based," at best. It is [i]not[/i] "historical." There's nothing wrong with that! But don't try to church up Old World with assertions of historicity.

[b]THE GOOD:[/b]
[b]1. City limits, workable tiles and specialists.[/b] There's usually a way to get what you want where you want it, though not necessarily when you need it. Borders can grow stupidly, which should be fixed, e.g., don't give that unincorporated wheat to my Champions city when my Landowners city is within equal range.

[b]2. The Ping system[/b] is great for planning improvements. Reminder pings need improvement. Setting a reminder ping to, say, promote a military unit on turn X will cause the ping message to post in the long list of messages delivered at the start of turn X, but the map pin is immediately removed! Leave time-sensitive pings on the map until they're acknowledged or removed manually.

[b]3. Undo is wonderful![/b] Make the Actions Stack viewable so that the player can easily select the last event they want to "keep" when they undo Actions.

[b]4. The Orders concept[/b] is an interesting constraint on player actions. Are the computer players also so constrained? The need for the player to decide which actions to take this turn (vs. later or maybe never) limits one's horizons, but it presents a challenge that's interesting to deal with.

[b]5. The Vassal Families system[/b] presents interesting challenges. Why aren't all 10 vassal families available to every civilization? Keep the limit of only three Families per empire. There's no good reason to arbitrarily make it impossible for a particular civilization to incorporate any of the different Vassal Families, so long as there are never more than three Families present in the empire.

[b]THE BAD:[/b]
[b]1. The Diplomacy system stinks.[/b] It's too limited and it's lame that an Ambassador is required in order to take any diplomatic action. It's reasonable to require an Ambassador to conduct diplomacy with other Civilizations. It's unreasonable to require an Ambassador to conduct diplomacy with Tribes. The few Ambassador Actions available suggest that the Diplomacy system was just bolted onto the game rather than developed right from the beginning. My Orders are better spent elsewhere.

[b]2. The Religion system stinks.[/b] Like Diplomacy, Religion seems like an afterthought. Civilizations without Clerics Families or that don't start the game with the Divination technology or with the Husbandry technology will almost never found a World Religion except by sheer accident due to a random Event. Pagan Religions are second-class to World Religions, making them a short-term sink of one's precious Orders, so why bother?

[b]3. The Espionage system is weak.[/b] It's reasonable to require a Spymaster to conduct Espionage Missions against other Civilizations. It's unreasonable to require a Spymaster to, e.g., "deal with" my rotten jealous scheming twin brother who lives forever and is an irredeemable nuisance and DEFCON 1 threat to my Rule and my household. It's completely arbitrary that all the nasty things one might need to do without being noticed within one's own civilization are off limits until one reaches the developmental stage at which it is also possible to foment unrest in foreign lands or steal technologies from adversaries. And Spymasters can't stir up the Tribes.

[b]4. Influence Actions are too limited.[/b] One Character can only attempt to Influence ("A chats up B") another Character exactly one time, ever, throughout the entire lives of both Characters (A and B). One Character can only be Interceded For ("C chats up B on A's behalf") one time, ever, throughout the entire lives of both principal Characters (A and B). And during Leadership transitions, womp womp Legitimacy tanks! Good luck getting all your VIPs happily in line. You get one shot and one shot only per Influence target. What am I, made of Orders? Better to spend them on sure things.

[b]THE UGLY:[/b]
[b]1. "Yo I heard you like reading."[/b] Everything that's not the map terrain itself is text. Tiny icons and tiny text litter the map, every notification is text... you'll do so much reading and clicking through menus in Old World that you'll suffer eye strain. Tooltips and text labels need different typefaces to separate and highlight different bits of information. The net effect is information overload. Animations and voice acting for Events would do wonders to liven things up.

[b]2. All the improvements look the same.[/b] Each improvement type looks identical across all Civilizations, lacking any national or regional character. Is it all made out of ticky-tacky?

[b]3. Tables, charts and graphs are more crude and ugly than useful.[/b] For example, the Family Opinion chart. One sees three traces plotted vs. time. Three numbers, that's it! Information, especially numerical data, is presented in a very limited and visually unappealing way that screams "SuSE Linux, circa 2003."

[b]4. The UI is fiddly and sticky.[/b] Tooltips with tooltips on their tooltips make for a very fiddly experience. There's a lot of clicking this and clicking that and having to drag the map this way and that, which worsens player fatigue caused by turn after turn of textalanche. Units cycle in a fixed order, bouncing from one end of the map to the other. One can automate Scouts and Workers, but military units need their hands held every step they take.

[h1]A Beautiful Disappointment: Ambition Without Execution[/h1]
I'm a history buff and a fan of 4X games, so Old World should have been perfect for me. The concept is compelling - a 4X game set in antiquity with dynastic mechanics and character-driven narratives. The art direction is beautiful, and I think the developers had good intentions. Unfortunately, that doesn't make up for the game's problems.
[hr][/hr]
[b]The Identity Crisis[/b]
Old World feels like it's trying to be three different games at once: Civilization's empire-building, Europa Universalis' depth, and Hearts of Iron's strategic complexity. It doesn't succeed at being any of them. It's stuck in an awkward middle ground where it's too shallow for grand strategy enthusiasts but too convoluted for casual 4X players.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Forced Ideology and Limited Agency[/b]
One of my biggest frustrations is how the game pushes contemporary cultural expectations and ideals into your face during gameplay. Mods can fix this (thankfully), but it shouldn't require community intervention to make a historical game feel less like social commentary. I play these games to engage with history on its own terms, not to have modern sensibilities imposed on ancient civilizations.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Shallow Systems[/b]
The problem-solving paths are severely gated and limited compared to what Europa Universalis offers. When challenges arise, you're forced down narrow story-driven solutions rather than having real strategic options. The economics feel underbaked, and production times are painfully long without the depth to justify it. Everything takes forever, but nothing feels particularly rewarding when completed.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Better Options Exist[/b]
I wanted this to work, but there are simply better games out there. If you want accessible 4X gameplay, Civilization V (or earlier) does it better. For grand strategy depth, Europa Universalis IV is superior. For character-driven narratives, Crusader Kings III excels. Even older games like Endless Legend or Endless Space offer more satisfying experiences.
Old World falls short in nearly every category it attempts. I can't recommend it when superior alternatives exist at similar or lower price points.

[h1]Multiplayer Wargame With 4X Foundation[/h1]

[h2]Fatigue, Information Overload and Ugliness Earn Old World A 2 Out of 5[/h2]

[b]THE GOOD: Cities and specialists; Pings; Undo; Orders; Vassal Families[/b]

[b]THE BAD: Diplomacy; Religion; Espionage; Influence Actions[/b]

[b]THE UGLY: Neverending text; Everything looks the same; Data displays are crude and ugly; A very rough UI[/b]

Old World is for lawyers and gamblers, not for engineers or accountants. It has some interesting concepts which enhance gameplay by exploiting the natural tension between freedom and constraints. I hope others duplicate the conceptual innovations in Old World and improve upon them in other 4X titles.

Old World's user interface is text- and number-dense. Playing beyond about four hours leads to a sense of fatigue and information overload. Things one might like to plan ahead of time, e.g. technological research or military unit promotions, are wrapped in random processes that appeal to devil-may-care gamblers but drive deliberate strategists mad. Frustration sets in when one tries to learn one's lessons from previous losses, only to be stymied because one can't make long-term plans for structural reasons intrinsic to the game. These structural aspects aggravate the information overload precisely because they make long-term strategic planning so exasperating.

Old World's intended audience is players seeking a Multiplayer Wargaming experience with a 4X foundation. Many (most?) experienced Old World players value the developers' attention to aspects of Multiplayer gameplay that were absent from or very poorly implemented in other 4X titles. I exclusively play Single Player, and though I enjoy stomping my annoying neighbors' guts out as much as anyone, that's not the only way I play 4X games. The victory conditions are boring, especially the Ambitions Victory, which, for structural reasons described previously, is challenging for all the wrong reasons.

Many positive reviewers on Steam reveal themselves to be unserious, as they are enthusiasts, fanbois and gatekeepers who abandon their critical faculties in defense of a game they believe is under-appreciated and not well publicized. Both of these things may be true of Old World but reviews don't settle scores. "Historical" justifications of Old World come either from fools or charlatans. The game's many grossly ahistorical elements are documented and criticized in detail elsewhere. Old World is "history based," at best. It is [i]not[/i] "historical." There's nothing wrong with that! But don't try to church up Old World with assertions of historicity.

[b]THE GOOD:[/b]
[b]1. City limits, workable tiles and specialists.[/b] There's usually a way to get what you want where you want it, though not necessarily when you need it. Borders can grow stupidly, which should be fixed, e.g., don't give that unincorporated wheat to my Champions city when my Landowners city is within equal range.

[b]2. The Ping system[/b] is great for planning improvements. Reminder pings need improvement. Setting a reminder ping to, say, promote a military unit on turn X will cause the ping message to post in the long list of messages delivered at the start of turn X, but the map pin is immediately removed! Leave time-sensitive pings on the map until they're acknowledged or removed manually.

[b]3. Undo is wonderful![/b] Make the Actions Stack viewable so that the player can easily select the last event they want to "keep" when they undo Actions.

[b]4. The Orders concept[/b] is an interesting constraint on player actions. Are the computer players also so constrained? The need for the player to decide which actions to take this turn (vs. later or maybe never) limits one's horizons, but it presents a challenge that's interesting to deal with.

[b]5. The Vassal Families system[/b] presents interesting challenges. Why aren't all 10 vassal families available to every civilization? Keep the limit of only three Families per empire. There's no good reason to arbitrarily make it impossible for a particular civilization to incorporate any of the different Vassal Families, so long as there are never more than three Families present in the empire.

[b]THE BAD:[/b]
[b]1. The Diplomacy system stinks.[/b] It's too limited and it's lame that an Ambassador is required in order to take any diplomatic action. It's reasonable to require an Ambassador to conduct diplomacy with other Civilizations. It's unreasonable to require an Ambassador to conduct diplomacy with Tribes. The few Ambassador Actions available suggest that the Diplomacy system was just bolted onto the game rather than developed right from the beginning. My Orders are better spent elsewhere.

[b]2. The Religion system stinks.[/b] Like Diplomacy, Religion seems like an afterthought. Civilizations without Clerics Families or that don't start the game with the Divination technology or with the Husbandry technology will almost never found a World Religion except by sheer accident due to a random Event. Pagan Religions are second-class to World Religions, making them a short-term sink of one's precious Orders, so why bother?

[b]3. The Espionage system is weak.[/b] It's reasonable to require a Spymaster to conduct Espionage Missions against other Civilizations. It's unreasonable to require a Spymaster to, e.g., "deal with" my rotten jealous scheming twin brother who lives forever and is an irredeemable nuisance and DEFCON 1 threat to my Rule and my household. It's completely arbitrary that all the nasty things one might need to do without being noticed within one's own civilization are off limits until one reaches the developmental stage at which it is also possible to foment unrest in foreign lands or steal technologies from adversaries. And Spymasters can't stir up the Tribes.

[b]4. Influence Actions are too limited.[/b] One Character can only attempt to Influence ("A chats up B") another Character exactly one time, ever, throughout the entire lives of both Characters (A and B). One Character can only be Interceded For ("C chats up B on A's behalf") one time, ever, throughout the entire lives of both principal Characters (A and B). And during Leadership transitions, womp womp Legitimacy tanks! Good luck getting all your VIPs happily in line. You get one shot and one shot only per Influence target. What am I, made of Orders? Better to spend them on sure things.

[b]THE UGLY:[/b]
[b]1. "Yo I heard you like reading."[/b] Everything that's not the map terrain itself is text. Tiny icons and tiny text litter the map, every notification is text... you'll do so much reading and clicking through menus in Old World that you'll suffer eye strain. Tooltips and text labels need different typefaces to separate and highlight different bits of information. The net effect is information overload. Animations and voice acting for Events would do wonders to liven things up.

[b]2. All the improvements look the same.[/b] Each improvement type looks identical across all Civilizations, lacking any national or regional character. Is it all made out of ticky-tacky?

[b]3. Tables, charts and graphs are more crude and ugly than useful.[/b] For example, the Family Opinion chart. One sees three traces plotted vs. time. Three numbers, that's it! Information, especially numerical data, is presented in a very limited and visually unappealing way that screams "SuSE Linux, circa 2003."

[b]4. The UI is fiddly and sticky.[/b] Tooltips with tooltips on their tooltips make for a very fiddly experience. There's a lot of clicking this and clicking that and having to drag the map this way and that, which worsens player fatigue caused by turn after turn of textalanche. Units cycle in a fixed order, bouncing from one end of the map to the other. One can automate Scouts and Workers, but military units need their hands held every step they take.

[h1]A Beautiful Disappointment: Ambition Without Execution[/h1]
I'm a history buff and a fan of 4X games, so Old World should have been perfect for me. The concept is compelling - a 4X game set in antiquity with dynastic mechanics and character-driven narratives. The art direction is beautiful, and I think the developers had good intentions. Unfortunately, that doesn't make up for the game's problems.
[hr][/hr]
[b]The Identity Crisis[/b]
Old World feels like it's trying to be three different games at once: Civilization's empire-building, Europa Universalis' depth, and Hearts of Iron's strategic complexity. It doesn't succeed at being any of them. It's stuck in an awkward middle ground where it's too shallow for grand strategy enthusiasts but too convoluted for casual 4X players.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Forced Ideology and Limited Agency[/b]
One of my biggest frustrations is how the game pushes contemporary cultural expectations and ideals into your face during gameplay. Mods can fix this (thankfully), but it shouldn't require community intervention to make a historical game feel less like social commentary. I play these games to engage with history on its own terms, not to have modern sensibilities imposed on ancient civilizations.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Shallow Systems[/b]
The problem-solving paths are severely gated and limited compared to what Europa Universalis offers. When challenges arise, you're forced down narrow story-driven solutions rather than having real strategic options. The economics feel underbaked, and production times are painfully long without the depth to justify it. Everything takes forever, but nothing feels particularly rewarding when completed.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Better Options Exist[/b]
I wanted this to work, but there are simply better games out there. If you want accessible 4X gameplay, Civilization V (or earlier) does it better. For grand strategy depth, Europa Universalis IV is superior. For character-driven narratives, Crusader Kings III excels. Even older games like Endless Legend or Endless Space offer more satisfying experiences.
Old World falls short in nearly every category it attempts. I can't recommend it when superior alternatives exist at similar or lower price points.

But don't try to church up Old World with assertions of historicity.

[b]THE GOOD:[/b]
[b]1. City limits, workable tiles and specialists.[/b] There's usually a way to get what you want where you want it, though not necessarily when you need it. Borders can grow stupidly, which should be fixed, e.g., don't give that unincorporated wheat to my Champions city when my Landowners city is within equal range.

[b]2. The Ping system[/b] is great for planning improvements. Reminder pings need improvement. Setting a reminder ping to, say, promote a military unit on turn X will cause the ping message to post in the long list of messages delivered at the start of turn X, but the map pin is immediately removed! Leave time-sensitive pings on the map until they're acknowledged or removed manually.

[b]3. Undo is wonderful![/b] Make the Actions Stack viewable so that the player can easily select the last event they want to "keep" when they undo Actions.

[b]4. The Orders concept[/b] is an interesting constraint on player actions. Are the computer players also so constrained? The need for the player to decide which actions to take this turn (vs. later or maybe never) limits one's horizons, but it presents a challenge that's interesting to deal with.

[b]5. The Vassal Families system[/b] presents interesting challenges. Why aren't all 10 vassal families available to every civilization? Keep the limit of only three Families per empire. There's no good reason to arbitrarily make it impossible for a particular civilization to incorporate any of the different Vassal Families, so long as there are never more than three Families present in the empire.

[b]THE BAD:[/b]
[b]1. The Diplomacy system stinks.[/b] It's too limited and it's lame that an Ambassador is required in order to take any diplomatic action. It's reasonable to require an Ambassador to conduct diplomacy with other Civilizations. It's unreasonable to require an Ambassador to conduct diplomacy with Tribes. The few Ambassador Actions available suggest that the Diplomacy system was just bolted onto the game rather than developed right from the beginning. My Orders are better spent elsewhere.

[b]2. The Religion system stinks.[/b] Like Diplomacy, Religion seems like an afterthought. Civilizations without Clerics Families or that don't start the game with the Divination technology or with the Husbandry technology will almost never found a World Religion except by sheer accident due to a random Event. Pagan Religions are second-class to World Religions, making them a short-term sink of one's precious Orders, so why bother?

[b]3. The Espionage system is weak.[/b] It's reasonable to require a Spymaster to conduct Espionage Missions against other Civilizations. It's unreasonable to require a Spymaster to, e.g., "deal with" my rotten jealous scheming twin brother who lives forever and is an irredeemable nuisance and DEFCON 1 threat to my Rule and my household. It's completely arbitrary that all the nasty things one might need to do without being noticed within one's own civilization are off limits until one reaches the developmental stage at which it is also possible to foment unrest in foreign lands or steal technologies from adversaries. And Spymasters can't stir up the Tribes.

[b]4. Influence Actions are too limited.[/b] One Character can only attempt to Influence ("A chats up B") another Character exactly one time, ever, throughout the entire lives of both Characters (A and B). One Character can only be Interceded For ("C chats up B on A's behalf") one time, ever, throughout the entire lives of both principal Characters (A and B). And during Leadership transitions, womp womp Legitimacy tanks! Good luck getting all your VIPs happily in line. You get one shot and one shot only per Influence target. What am I, made of Orders? Better to spend them on sure things.

[b]THE UGLY:[/b]
[b]1. "Yo I heard you like reading."[/b] Everything that's not the map terrain itself is text. Tiny icons and tiny text litter the map, every notification is text... you'll do so much reading and clicking through menus in Old World that you'll suffer eye strain. Tooltips and text labels need different typefaces to separate and highlight different bits of information. The net effect is information overload. Animations and voice acting for Events would do wonders to liven things up.

[b]2. All the improvements look the same.[/b] Each improvement type looks identical across all Civilizations, lacking any national or regional character. Is it all made out of ticky-tacky?

[b]3. Tables, charts and graphs are more crude and ugly than useful.[/b] For example, the Family Opinion chart. One sees three traces plotted vs. time. Three numbers, that's it! Information, especially numerical data, is presented in a very limited and visually unappealing way that screams "SuSE Linux, circa 2003."

[b]4. The UI is fiddly and sticky.[/b] Tooltips with tooltips on their tooltips make for a very fiddly experience. There's a lot of clicking this and clicking that and having to drag the map this way and that, which worsens player fatigue caused by turn after turn of textalanche. Units cycle in a fixed order, bouncing from one end of the map to the other. One can automate Scouts and Workers, but military units need their hands held every step they take.

[h1]A Beautiful Disappointment: Ambition Without Execution[/h1]
I'm a history buff and a fan of 4X games, so Old World should have been perfect for me. The concept is compelling - a 4X game set in antiquity with dynastic mechanics and character-driven narratives. The art direction is beautiful, and I think the developers had good intentions. Unfortunately, that doesn't make up for the game's problems.
[hr][/hr]
[b]The Identity Crisis[/b]
Old World feels like it's trying to be three different games at once: Civilization's empire-building, Europa Universalis' depth, and Hearts of Iron's strategic complexity. It doesn't succeed at being any of them. It's stuck in an awkward middle ground where it's too shallow for grand strategy enthusiasts but too convoluted for casual 4X players.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Forced Ideology and Limited Agency[/b]
One of my biggest frustrations is how the game pushes contemporary cultural expectations and ideals into your face during gameplay. Mods can fix this (thankfully), but it shouldn't require community intervention to make a historical game feel less like social commentary. I play these games to engage with history on its own terms, not to have modern sensibilities imposed on ancient civilizations.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Shallow Systems[/b]
The problem-solving paths are severely gated and limited compared to what Europa Universalis offers. When challenges arise, you're forced down narrow story-driven solutions rather than having real strategic options. The economics feel underbaked, and production times are painfully long without the depth to justify it. Everything takes forever, but nothing feels particularly rewarding when completed.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Better Options Exist[/b]
I wanted this to work, but there are simply better games out there. If you want accessible 4X gameplay, Civilization V (or earlier) does it better. For grand strategy depth, Europa Universalis IV is superior. For character-driven narratives, Crusader Kings III excels. Even older games like Endless Legend or Endless Space offer more satisfying experiences.
Old World falls short in nearly every category it attempts. I can't recommend it when superior alternatives exist at similar or lower price points.
